results.title: Settle down country
results.creator_credit: David Batty, Jim Buckell, Pam Nathan, CAAC, CAAMA, NAIHO and Western Deserts Oustations Council
results.brief_description: Documents the return of the Pintubi people to their own lands after many years on Government run settlements. Extensive use of archival footage offers an added historical perspective to this account of the efforts of these people to retain their cultural heritage. Based on the book of the same name by Dick Leichleitner Japanangka and Pam Nathan.

results.title: Aboriginal bark painting
results.creator_credit: Latrobe University. School of Education. Media Centre
results.brief_description: Made in partnership with the Barinaga Aboriginal Co-operative at Maningrida, Northern Territory. Provides an informative look at the bark paintings of Arnhem Land, placing the art work firmly in the context of Aboriginal belief systems and using traditional techniques. A useful complement to “The art and craft of Maningrida”. Narrated by Robin Cuming.

results.title: Whitewashed
results.creator_credit: Sue Ross and New South Wales Institute of Technology
results.brief_description: Examines the removal of Aboriginal children from their families and their placement in foster homes with white parents, the effect upon the children and the continuation of the practice in NSW today.

results.title: 14's good, 18's better
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Hilary Linstead, Timothy Read, Big Picture, Film Australia and M and L
results.brief_description: A longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, now 18, intercut with footage from “Smokes and lollies”, shot when they were 14. Their previous expectations have been altered by the experiences of marriage, parenthood, employment, low incomes and insecurity. However, they remain optimistic, with their humour intact. (Awards: Winner, Best Australian Educational Short Film, Australian Teachers of Media (ATOM) Awards, 1982)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Hilary Linstead, Timothy Read, Big Picture, Film Australia and M and L

results.title: Call of the country
results.creator_credit: Melanie Guiney and James Cook University
results.brief_description: On remote Cape York Peninsula, the Pormpuraaw Aboriginal Community and scientists from the Anthropology and Geography departments of James Cook University are joining together to map the cultural, ecological and environmental heritage of their country. For many of the custodians it is their first trip home for many years and represents the renewal of an old and intimate relationship with the land. Through this bringing together of ancient understanding and modern methods it is hoped to preserve the past for the protection of the future.
results.description: On remote Cape York Peninsula, the Pormpuraaw Aboriginal Community and scientists from the Anthropology and Geography departments of James Cook University are joining together to map the cultural, ecological and environmental heritage of their country. results.title: Picture books on video. - Volume 2 = Turramulli and the giant Quinkin
results.creator_credit: Catharine Campbell, Cathy Miller and Video Classroom
results.brief_description: Three Aboriginal Dreamtime stories. “Turramulli the giant Quinkin” and “Banana Bird and the Snake men” are both written by Percy Trezise, illustrated by Dick Roughsey and narrated by Bob Maza. “The Frog and the pelican” is written by Des O’Brien. The stories are narrated with background music as the illustrations are shown on screen.

results.title: Chocolates, giants and peaches. Parts 1, 2 and 3
results.creator_credit: Lily Steiner, Statewide School Support and Victoria. Ministry of Education
results.brief_description: Roald Dahl, recorded live at the Dallas Brooks Hall in Melbourne, talks about his writing and reads aloud from his own books, including Revolting Rhymes”, “BFG”, “Charlie and the Chocolate Factory”, “Matilda and “Dirty Beasts”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lily Steiner, Statewide School Support and Victoria. Ministry of Education

results.title: Market of dreams
results.brief_description: With little understanding of the meanings or the origins of Australian Aboriginal art, the international art market has eagerly, almost obscenely, embraced this most ancient cultural tradition. This significant, ironic documentary does not presume to make judgements on the artists and the analysts, the prophets and the profiteers, the critics and collectors. The images and stories speak for themselves. Features artists, Ronnie Tjampitjinpa, Michael Jagamara Nelson, Darby Jampijinpa, Dolly Nampijinpo Granites, Uta Uta Tjangala and Turkey Tolson Tjupurrlo. Gold Medal Winner, International Film & Television Festival, New York, 1991.

results.title: A Real man's job: Images of Australian women in wartime [kit]
results.creator_credit: Felicity Cockram, Australian War Memorial, History Teacher's Association of Victoria and ImMEDIAte Action
results.brief_description: Subtitled Images of Australian women in wartime this kit aims to identify the real contribution that women made during both world wars and also at the images of women in wartime that were projected. Authored by Tim Gurry, Robert Lewis and Richard Reid, the kit draws together a wide variety of material with suggestions for its use, into nine Evidence Files, a videocassette and Teacher’s notes.

results.title: The Future of Our Press
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Journalism Resource Tapes”.
Creighton Burns, Editor of the Age and Harry Gordon former Editor in Chief of the Herald and Weekly Times discuss the current decline of the newspaper industry. They give their opinions and make their predictions as to the future of journalism and the newspaper houses.
